original_title: Moody experts — How mood and expertise influence judgmental anchoring
processed_title: Moody experts — How mood and expertise influence judgmental anchoring
content: Published online by Cambridge University Press:  01 January 2023 Anchoring effects, the assimilation of numerical estimates to previously considered standards, are highly robust. Two studies examined whether mood and expertise jointly moderate the magnitude of anchoring. Previous research has demonstrated that happy mood induces judges to process information in a less thorough manner than sad mood, which means that happy judges tend to be more susceptible to unwanted influences. However, this may not be true for anchoring effects. Because anchoring results from an elaborate process of selective knowledge activation, more thorough processing should lead to more anchoring; as a result, sad judges should show stronger anchoring effects than happy judges and happy judges may even remain uninfluenced by the given anchors. Because information processing of experts may be relatively independent of their mood, however, mood may influence anchoring only in non-experts. Results of two studies on legal decision-making (Study 1) and numeric estimates (Study 2) are consistent with these expectations. These findings suggest that, at least for non-experts, positive mood may eliminate the otherwise robust anchoring effect. Human judgment is shaped by affective influences. How people judge and evaluate a given target critically depends on how they feel (for a recent review, see Schwarz & Clore, Reference Schwarz, Clore, Higgins and Kruglanski2007). Judges’ mood, for example, influences how they judge their own lives (Schwarz & Clore, Reference Schwarz and Clore1983), other persons (Ottati & Isbell, Reference Ottati and Isbell1996), or the frequency of risks (Johnson & Tversky, Reference Johnson and Tversky1983). These effects might occur because judges tend to use their mood as information in the judgment process (Schwarz & Clore, Reference Schwarz and Clore1983). However, moods influence human judgments not only because they are used directly as information, but also because they exert a more indirect influence by changing how judges process information. In particular, judges who are in a happy mood tend to process information in a more superficial or heuristic manner, whereas those in a sad mood tend to process information more thoroughly (Schwarz, Reference Schwarz, Higgins and Sorrentino1990, Reference Schwarz1998). For example, judges in a happy mood rely more on the use of stereotypes (Bodenhausen, Kramer, & Süsser, Reference Bodenhausen, Kramer and Süsser1994) and other heuristic strategies (Isen & Means, Reference Isen and Means1983; Mackie & Worth, Reference Mackie and Worth1989) than judges in a sad mood (Bodenhausen, Sheppard & Kramer, Reference Bodenhausen, Sheppard and Kramer1993; Bless, Bohner, Schwarz & Strack, Reference Bless, Bohner, Schwarz and Strack1990). To the extent that the use of such heuristic strategies leads to judgmental biases (Tversky & Kahneman, Reference Tversky and Kahneman1974), these findings suggest that happy judges are typically less accurate and more biased than sad judges. However, there appears to be at least one notable exception to this rule – judgmental anchoring. Judgmental anchoring — the assimilation of a numeric judgment towards a previously considered number — is known to be a strikingly robust phenomenon. Anchoring effects have been demonstrated in a diversity of judgmental domains (for reviews see Chapman & Johnson, Reference Chapman, Johnson, Gilovich, Griffin and Kahneman2002; Epley, Reference Epley, Koehler and Harvey2004; Mussweiler, Englich & Strack, Reference Mussweiler, Englich, Strack and Pohl2004) and result from exposure to implausible as well as plausible anchors (Chapman & Johnson, Reference Chapman and Johnson1994; Mussweiler & Strack, Reference Mussweiler and Strack1999; Strack & Mussweiler, Reference Strack and Mussweiler1997). summary: Penelitian ini mengungkapkan bahwa perasaan dan keahlian memengaruhi efek *anchoring* dalam pengambilan keputusan. *Anchoring* adalah kecenderungan manusia untuk menyesuaikan estimasi dengan angka atau nilai awal yang telah diberikan. Penelitian menunjukkan bahwa orang yang dalam keadaan senang cenderung memproses informasi lebih dangkal, sehingga lebih rentan terpengaruh oleh nilai awal (anchor), sementara orang yang sedih cenderung memproses informasi lebih mendalam dan lebih terpengaruh oleh anchor tersebut. Namun, hasil penelitian menunjukkan bahwa keadaan senang justru mengurangi efek *anchoring* pada orang yang bukan ahli (non-expert), karena mereka lebih cenderung mengabaikan nilai awal karena proses pemrosesan informasi yang lebih menyeluruh. Sebaliknya, bagi ahli (expert), perasaan tidak memengaruhi besar efek *anchoring*, karena mereka mampu mengintegrasikan informasi secara lebih terstruktur dan independen dari perasaan. Dalam konteks keputusan hukum dan estimasi angka, ini berarti bahwa orang yang tidak memiliki keahlian dalam bidang tertentu lebih rentan terpengaruh oleh nilai awal ketika berada dalam keadaan senang. Namun, ahli tetap mengandalkan penilaian yang lebih objektif. Temuan ini menekankan bahwa perasaan memengaruhi keputusan manusia, tetapi keahlian dapat mengimbangi pengaruh emosional tersebut. Dalam konteks psikologi Islam, hal ini dapat dihubungkan dengan *tazkiyatun nufus*—proses perbaikan jiwa yang mendorong keputusan yang lebih bijaksana dan terbebas dari pengaruh emosional.
